I once asked NASA Administrator and former astronaut Charles Bolden what NASA’s constancy of purpose should be, and without hesitation he said "science."

WFIRST and NASA's other top scientific priorities deserve support and funding from Congress.  https://beyer.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=1308 … 6/6

Despite the enormous scientific value of WFIRST, the Trump FY2020 budget recommended total elimination of funding. Congress must not let that happen.

I'm working with my @HouseScience colleagues to protect funding for WFIRST and the scientific progress it represents. 5/ pic.twitter.com/Ch3o9D6D9u

The scientific value of the WFIRST mission is so great that, in a 2010 survey of astronomers and astrophysicists, it was identified as the top priority large project for the coming decade. It's of huge importance to the future of astronomy.  https://science.nasa.gov/researchers/sara/grant-solicitations/wide-field-infrared-survey-telescope-wfirst … 4/

This mission is of great value to scientists because it will aid in the pursuit of the mysteries of dark energy and dark matter, and greatly boost our search for exoplanets. 3/ https://wfirst.gsfc.nasa.gov/

The Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST) is a scientific mission to build a telescope that would have both the scope to see vast swathes of the sky and the power to see them in great detail. As @NASA describes it, "the best of both worlds." 2/ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LbJpVHMV1m4 …

I want to thank cosponsors @RepRaskin @RepMcGovern @RoKhanna @repjimcooper @RepScottPeters for their support, and nonpartisan organizations including @fairvote @repwomen @FemMajority for helping with this ambitious legislation. Read more about it here: 5/5 https://beyer.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=4487 …

At a time when Americans have waning faith in institutions and political leadership, the Fair Representation Act would help restore the trust which so many have lost in our political system, and make genuine bipartisanship for progress a possibility. 4/

Congressional districts across the country would suddenly become competitive. The votes of Democrats in rural districts and Republicans in urban ones would have stronger impacts. It would create new pathways to elect women and candidates of color, while weakening partisanship. 3/

The Fair Representation Act would move US House elections into multi-member districts drawn by independent redistricting commissions, elected through ranked choice voting.

These measures would give congressional candidates incentives to appeal to a broader range of voters. 2/

Last month the Supreme Court issued a ruling in @CommonCause v. Rucho upholding political gerrymandering. It was a bad decision that will hurt our democracy.

Today I introduced the Fair Representation Act, which would end gerrymandering, and do more to improve our elections. 1/ pic.twitter.com/n59pQb5QzS

Our duty in this historic moment was clear.

My colleagues and I did not seek office to impeach anyone, but today we were forced to do so by a lawless president who will stop at nothing to hold onto power.

Our oaths require us to defend the Constitution, and that is what we did.

It is important that we have a national conversation about suicide, and a national strategy to address it. CDC data shows that suicides in the United States have risen by a third in the past two decades; over 47,000 Americans took their own lives in 2017. https://www.cdc.gov/vitalsigns/suicide/ …

The basic idea is simple: restricting access to lethal means allows time for a feeling of crisis to pass, and for people experiencing suicidal thoughts to seek help.

Numerous studies back this up, but often state & local governments need help securing funding to build barriers.

Today @RepJohnKatko @gracenapolitano and I introduced the Barriers to Suicide Act.

I believe that my constituents are right, and I support the initiation of an impeachment inquiry to examine evidence of criminal acts committed by President Trump.

The most important consideration for me in evaluating whether this course of action is correct has been the views of my constituents.

Their belief in the need to launch an impeachment inquiry – as expressed to me in calls, letters, and conversations – has grown to a crescendo.

Congressman Amash’s brave public statement makes support for an impeachment inquiry bipartisan, and I have privately spoken to other Republicans who believe he is right but are unwilling to say so publicly.

...and I have every confidence in the ability of my colleagues on the House Judiciary Committee and in the Speaker and her leadership team to pursue such an inquiry if they determine that it is the proper course.

From the first time I was asked about impeachment I have always said that I believed that such a serious action must be fully justified by the facts, must be done with great care, and it must have bipartisan support. I believe the facts fully justify an impeachment inquiry...

...but the President’s illegal cover-up, most recently evidenced by his preventing the Secretary of the Treasury and the former White House Counsel from honoring Congressional subpoenas, leaves us little recourse to do so.

We are aware of other potential crimes committed by this President, including tax fraud and violations of campaign finance laws, both alleged under oath by his former attorney. 

Congress must investigate these allegations to determine their veracity...

The behavior described in the redacted Mueller Report meets every standard for the classification of ‘obstruction of justice’ of which I am aware.

He has compounded that fact by engaging in illegal stonewalling of Congress as my colleagues and I have engaged in oversight.
President Trump has shown utter contempt for the Constitution from the moment he took office, but we are now faced with evidence of actions that strongly resemble high crimes and misdemeanors.

Endorsing such a course is not easy, and I do not do so lightly, but I believe that the President has left Congress no other option.

When I came to Congress I swore an oath ‘to defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic.’
The time has come for the House of Representatives to open an impeachment inquiry into the conduct of President Trump. pic.twitter.com/WXOmMCakl0

Trump tweeted, he pitched tantrums, and he gave an address. Nowhere did he give any reason why the government should remain shut down.

Every day he refuses to end this shutdown and reopen the government worsens this man-made disaster for our region and our country. It must end.

Keeping these people off the job or making them work unpaid doesn't make us safer; anyone with an ounce of sense would tell you that sacrificing the service of these trained professionals in order to waste money on ancient technology that can be crossed with a ladder is foolish.

I've heard from furloughed FBI agents, air traffic controllers, State Department officials, workers at TSA, the Department of Homeland Security, the Coast Guard, and even Customs and Border Patrol, all of whom vehemently oppose the shutdown.

I've heard from a couple, both federal employees protecting the country, who don't know how they will make their upcoming tuition payments for their children’s college.

I've heard from single mothers who aren't sure where the money is going to come from to feed their kids.

I've heard from a disabled veteran who owns a small business that depends on government contracts, who said he may soon have to decide between taking out loans or laying off his employees.

I've heard from a contractor who does not know how they will pay for her health care costs

I've gotten hundreds of calls and letters, and they overwhelmingly oppose the shutdown.

I've heard from people living in anguish and fear, not knowing where the money is going to come from to pay for their tuition, their rent, their groceries, or their health care.

I represent about 80,000 federal employees and thousands more contractors and family members of government workers. They are getting crushed by Trump's shutdown.

Trump said a lot of words last night, but not one of them was about the federal workforce.

The Atlantic Seismic Airgun Protection Act would stop these blasting permits in the Atlantic. This bill is ready to go, and it has wide bipartisan support from Members representing nearly every Atlantic seaboard state. 

We should pass it ASAP. 9/9

It is important that the incoming Democratic majority take steps to address climate change by crafting legislation. That's something I've worked on for years.

But we also have to step up oversight and use our majority to fight Trump's backwards steps that put lives at risk. 8/

The Trump Administration knows that climate change is killing people and costing huge amounts of money. But with this step today, as with their decision to roll back the Clean Power Plan and other efforts to fight climate change, they are instead actively making it worse. 7/

The Trump Administration also quietly tried to bury findings by the US Geological Survey showing exploitation of federal lands, including offshore drilling, made up nearly 1/4 of all US greenhouse gas emissions from 2005-2014.

This is a big deal. 6/  https://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2018/5131/sir20185131.pdf?wpisrc=nl_energy202&wpmm=1 …

A week ago the National Climate Assessment made it clear that climate change is killing Americans and costing billions of dollars.

Trump and his Cabinet have spent the week engaging in willful ignorance of scientific findings, and now they are pushing more dirty energy. 5/

Even in a time of economic hardship the risks posed by Trump's actions would outweigh the benefits.

There is absolutely no justification for intentionally welcoming this kind of damage at a time when oil prices are low and fossil fuel corporations are posting record profits. 4/

These are just some of the reasons why coastal states, communities, small businesses, political leaders from both parties, and the United States Navy all stand united in opposition to drilling, seismic blasting, and invasive petroleum exploration in the Atlantic Ocean. 3/

Seismic blasting poses a major threat to marine life, including the critically endangered North Atlantic right whale, which is on the verge of extinction.

The potential for harm to marine life from blasting and drilling also poses a serious danger to the coastal economies. 2/
